title: Type 2 Diabetes and Your Environment

content: As an advocate, I hear a lot of discussions surrounding type 2 diabetes, talking about prevalence, self-management, treatment, care, and more. Most delve into a person’s lifestyle, habits, and past choices. But what if I told you that the geographical area that you live in, and the resources you have – or don’t have – access to as a result of living there, play a major part in how likely you are to have type 2 diabetes?

The conditions of where and how you live are called social determinants of health. If something’s lacking in any one of these social determinants, it can lead to poorer health conditions for the members of that community. According to the CDC, there are five main social determinants of health:

Healthcare access and quality. This refers to what doctor's offices, clinics, hospitals, hospitals, urgent care facilities, pharmacies, and other health care organizations are located in a particular geographical area.

In areas that lack places where people can get routine checkups, seek emergency medical attention, or pick up prescriptions, residents either have to travel farther for adequate care or they don’t receive it at all.

content: For people who are predisposed to or diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, this can present a serious problem. Without access to adequate healthcare services, they’re left to spend more money as they try to access these services or play a guessing game and go by how they feel to decide whether or not they need medical attention.

Education access and quality. Lack of educational institutions in an area can make it a challenge to prepare to create a better quality of life. Quality education can lead to getting a better job, and a better job can lead to more earning potential. This can then itself lead to actually earning a decent living and being able to take care of everything that a family needs to live.

In areas with a higher prevalence of diabetes and other chronic illnesses, you’ll often find that the people there have lower incomes than average. This doesn’t mean that these are the only areas where people with diabetes and other chronic illnesses live, but these conditions are more common in these places than where incomes are higher.

sections.heading: Economic stability.
content: This social determinant of health is linked to education access and quality.

It means how well the economy is doing in a given area. The types of businesses in a place and how successful they are makes a difference for the people who live there. Employment rates can also affect the ability of people to take care of their needs and those of their families through jobs and entrepreneurship. When looking for a place for a family to settle and grow, it’s better to be in an area where finances flow freely between producers and consumers.

Social and community context. This refers to the places in a community where people gather socially, such as houses of worship, community centers, and civic groups. Social groups have statistically been proven to improve morale among individuals with similar interests.

Resources like these help to foster learning environments among peers. They’re also a way for people to break through the barrier of feeling alone without other people to care for them emotionally and mentally. When it comes to people who are living with chronic illnesses, social support is a great solution to a multifaceted problem.

sections.heading: Neighborhoods and built environments
content: . These are the structures and organizations that help people get around and provide a certain level of safety: things like sidewalks, bike trails, parks, public transportation, and police stations.

As health educators, we recommend that people get regular physical activity. We tell them you don't need a gym membership to get those 150 minutes per week, but if an area doesn’t make physical activity easy and safe, there won’t be any outdoor physical activity. This is important, because we know exercise is a must when managing a chronic illness like type 2 diabetes, and while there’s a fee for the gym and home workouts aren’t always possible, outdoors is always free.

One thing that makes a neighborhood a dangerous environment for outdoor physical activity is if there aren’t any sidewalks. And disability structures like accessible curb corners, walkways, and public transit stops make a difference in making outdoor physical activities available to everyone.

content: It’s also difficult to travel to things like doctor visits if someone doesn’t have their own transportation or public transit to rely on.

Neighborhoods should also have a law enforcement presence, including police patrols and stations and neighborhood watches. This has been a common complaint among the participants in the diabetes peer support network that I lead.

Another challenge in a neighborhood environment that may affect someone trying to create a healthier lifestyle for themselves and their families is “food deserts.”  There are some geographical areas that have more convenience stores, fast food outlets, and liquor stores than grocery stores. Unhealthy food is the popular option because it’s cheaper and accessible.

For people who live in areas like this, it can be harder to manage type 2 diabetes because the things that we tell them are necessary to do it properly aren’t easily accessible to them. We tell them to eat healthier, but there's nowhere to find fresh produce. We tell them to visit their doctor regularly, but there aren’t any clinics nearby. We tell them to do more physical activity, but either there isn't a gym near them, they can't afford a membership, or their neighborhood lacks sidewalks or isn’t safe enough to take a walk.

content: This has become a growing problem as the prevalence of type 2 diabetes continues to rise. I believe that we need to pay closer attention to the social determinants of health. There isn’t one single solution to solve these problems, but there are some steps that we can take can to ease these issues for the people who need relief the most.
